contentrichtext.text: {{italic title}} {{taxobox |name = ''Geranium robertianum''<br>Herb Robert |image = Herb-Robert 800.jpg |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_subclassis = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Geraniales]] |familia = [[Geraniaceae]] |genus = ''[[Geranium]]'' |species = '''''G. robertianum''''' |binomial = ''Geranium robertianum'' |binomial_authority = [[Carolus Linnaeus|L.]] |}} '''''Geranium robertianum''''', ([[syn.]] '''''Robertiella robertiana''''') commonly known as''' Herb Robert''', '''Red Robin''',''' Death come quickly''', '''Storksbill''', '''Dove's Foot''', Crow's Foot, or (in North America) '''Robert Geranium''', is a common species of [[cranesbill]] in [[Europe]], [[Asia]], [[North America]], and [[North Africa]]. ''Geranium robertianum'' can grow at altitudes of up to {{convert|1500|m|ft|0}}. It grows as an [[annual plant|annual]] or [[biennial plant]], producing small, pink, five-petalled [[flower]]s (about 1 cm in diameter) from April until the autumn. The [[Leaf|leaves]] are fern-like, and the stems often reddish; the leaves too turn red at the end of the flowering season. The plant has little root structure. In [[Great Britain]] is commonly found in [[hedgerow]]s. It has been [[introduced species|introduced]] into other temperate parts of the world, probably through its use as an [[ornamental plant]], such as in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]] in [[California]]. In the state of [[Washington (state)|Washington]], it is known as Stinky Bob and classified as a [[noxious weed]].{{harv|WSNWCB|2005|p=8}}{{harv|WSNWCB|2007}} ==Uses== In traditional [[herbalism]], Herb Robert was used as a remedy for toothache and nosebleeds.<ref>{{cite book|last=Foster|first=Steven|title=Desk Reference To Nature's Medicine|year=2006|publisher=National Geographic Society|location=Washington, DC|isbn=10: 0-7922-3666-1|pages=210â€“11}}</ref> Freshly picked leaves have an odor resembling burning tires when crushed, and if they are rubbed on the body the smell is said to repel [[mosquito]]es. The active ingredients are [[tannins]], a bitter compound called geraniin, and [[essential oils]]. It was carried to attract good luck, and due to its analogical association with storks, to enhance fertility.{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} == References == <references /> * {{Citation | author=Blanchan, Neltje | title=[[Wild Flowers Worth Knowing]] | year=2005 | publisher=[[Project Gutenberg|Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation]] | authorlink=Neltje Blanchan}} * {{Citation | author=Isabell Shipard | title=How can I use HERBS in my daily life? | year=2003 }} * {{Citation | author=Peter Loewer | title=The Wild Gardener | year=1991 }} * {{Citation|publisher=Washington State Noxious Weed Control Board|title=Selected Noxious Weeds of Washington State|last=WSNWCB|year=2005}} * {{Citation|url=http://www.nwcb.wa.gov/weed_info/Written_findings/Geranium_robertianum.html|title=Herb Robert (Geranium robertianum)|work=Written Findings of the State Noxious Weed Control Board - Class B - B-designate Weed|publisher=State of Washington|date=2007-03-31|last=WSNWCB}} [[File:Geranium robertianum buds.jpg|300px|thumb|''Geranium robertianum flower buds'']] [[File:Geranium robertianum.jpg|300px|thumb|''Geranium robertianum'']] == External links == {{Commons category|Geranium robertianum|''Geranium robertianum'' - Herb Robert}} *[http://www.bioimages.org.uk/HTML/T593.HTM Images at Bioimages (UK)] *[http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/cgi-bin/get_JM_treatment.pl?Geranium+robertianum Species treatment from the Jepson Manual] *[http://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Geranium+robertianum Entry in the Plants for a Future database] *[http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=GERO USDA plants Profile: ''Geranium robertianum''] *{{ITIS |id=29119 |taxon=''Geranium robertianum''}} [[Category:Geranium|robertianum]] [[Category:Flora of the Mediterranean]] [[Category:Flora of Western Asia]] [[Category:Flora of North Africa]] [[Category:Flora of Palestine]] [[Category:Medicinal plants of Africa]] [[Category:Medicinal plants of Asia]] [[Category:Medicinal plants of Europe]] [[Category:Garden plants of Europe]] [[Category:Invasive plant species in Oregon]] {{medicinal-plant-stub}} {{rosid-stub}}
